ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt more about European Economic History, a subject that is given short-shrift in an otherwise America-heavy social science department.

I learned a lot about how to apply basic economic principles (the kind learned in ECON115 and 116) to a broad swath of historical cases across Europe. This really boosted my understanding of these principles from the abstract to be more concrete. I also learned a ton about the economics of 18th and 19th century Europe (obviously), which really helped my understanding of the general history of the continent in a far more fundamental way than I anticipated.
Big picture yet comprehensive understanding of western European economic history in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Improved ability to write clearly and concisely.

I was able to gain a complete picture of how 19th Century European economies operated and developed, allowing for the depth to properly evaluate other historical events at this time. We also practiced purely concise, descriptive writing.
Analytic skills applied to social science understanding.
Economic thinking applied to historical trends and topics.
Knowledge of European history in an economic context, and how logically certain processes in European economic history stem from previous events

I learned the economic developments of Europe in the 19th century.  I also learned how to evaluate economic papers and learned a new style of writing by essentially providing summaries of these readings.
A broad view of how European economies developed and the factors behind this

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the no-lecture-slides and no-recording policy of the class, since it placed more emphasis on attendance and engagement. The absence policy is very generous and much appreciated especially during more difficult seasons.

The course is great at cramming tons of information about such a wide region across a fair amount of time into your head I am walking away knowing far more about the undercurrents of European history than I walked in, and I study European history for my major! Professor Guinnane is a real strength, his no-nonsense (except some truly corny if fun jokes) makes sure you are learning and understand why you are learning. 

A weakness would definitely be the problem sets there are only three, but they are pretty disconnected from the sort of material you learn in class. Imagine you are taking a history lecture with an occasional supply/demand graph thrown in every once in a while and some econ jargon, and then all of sudden your pset has you scrambling for your ECON116 notes again. It's very doable, and the TF Office Hours are a godsend, but it was a bit of a weak point incorporating more of the problems into lecture could have been nice.
The course is perfectly structured in my opinion: small lecture, great professor, interesting content, helpful assignments.

It's a great class. teaches you a lot about how to think about the world in terms of economics.

It's hard to keep up with the note taking.
Lectures are incredibly helpful and informative.
Prof. G is great
Not much instruction is given on how to do the problem sets in lecture but there is help available in office hours if you go.

I think the course offered wide variety of topics that were interesting.  While the course had a lot of interesting content, I think there was too much reading.  Also, the course wasn't very user-friendly with exams as you are not allowed to ask questions during them.
The psets were very helpful is solidifying technical knowledge

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is a refreshing format of economics classes that is quite hard to come by at Yale.

This course is fantastic for a lot of types of people. As a history major, I feel I am walking away with a far better understanding not just of the actual history of the region but why the sorts of phenomena my other classes discuss might be occurring. I don't know how useful it is to the overall Econ major.

As a general student, I would still recommend the class its not too hard, and the topic covered (if you think you might find it interesting) is really rewarding to learn and apply to the rest of one's studies.

Yes, if you are interested in this topic. If you have no interest in economics, history, or economic history, then you may not enjoy the class just for the content itself. If you do want to learn more about it, this is perfect for you.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in history, economics, development, or any other areas overlapping with these.
Yes, because it teaches you econ abilities to think about social science narratives you've been hearing throughout your life.
Yes, I would recommend this course. Very interesting perspective on macro historical trends.
Yes
Yes
I would recommend this course to someone interested in the history of Europe through an economic perspective.
Yes - very useful for history majors
